summary: autophagy is a highly conserved and tightly regulated process in which cellular components are engulfed into double-membrane vesicles. this process begins with a negative membrane curvature which expands and encloses the cytosolic cargo, forming the autophagosome. the initiation of autophagosome formation is negatively regulated by the mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1 (mTORC1) kinase. autophagy is essential for cell viability under stress conditions, including viral infections. a central aspect of the autophagic antiviral activity is to promote viral clearance by degradation of viral components. autophagy also contributes to the innate and adaptive immunity by boosting the delivery of toll-like receptor ligands to endosomes. the bipartite genome encodes four proteins: the matrix protein Z, the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase L, the major nucleocapsid protein N, and the glycoprotein precursor GPC [18]. clathrin-mediated endocytosis is the main route used by JUNV and involves the cytoskeleton and other cellular proteins [21,22]. rabbit polyclonal antibody against JUNV N protein [30] or mouse monoclonal antibodies (mAb) obtained through BEI Resources, NIAID, NIH: Monoclonal anti-Junin Virus, Clone SA02-BG12 (produced in vitro), NR-49274 and Clone NA05-AG12 (produced in vitro) were used.
